entry.title: Re: Inquiry: Unexpected "Never" (1) Setting for Purchase...
entry.content:
This issue, where the "Reservation/Purchase Req." indicator in a Production Order's external processing tab is intermittently set to '1' (Never), typically occurs when certain system validations fail during order creation or release, overriding the default configuration.

  • Credit Holds on Sales Orders: For Make-to-Order (MTO) scenarios, if the parent Sales Order is on credit hold when the Production Order is released, the system may set the indicator to '1' (Never) because it cannot proceed with external procurement for a blocked sales requirement. Note that releasing the credit hold later may not automatically reset this indicator to '3' (Immediately); manual intervention is often required.
  • Control Key Configuration: If the control key assigned to the operation is configured with the "External Processing" flag as 'X' (Internally processed/external possible) instead of '+' (Externally processed), the system may fail to generate a Purchase Requisition (PR) correctly.
    • Resolution: Verify settings in SAP Customizing under Define Control Key (ID 500223) and ensure the "External Processing" field is set to '+'.
  • Missing API Data: If the order is created or modified via an API (e.g., Project Network API), the indicator may default to "Never" if mandatory material planning fields are missing from the call, even if the plant-level default is "Immediately".
  • Incomplete Master Data: Intermittent resets can occur if there is missing data in the operation's detail screen (such as Material Group or Purchasing Group) during the conversion of a planned order to a production order.
Relevant SAP Notes & KBAs
While specific note numbers often change with versioning, the following are closely related to these symptoms:
  • KBA 3558196: Addresses PR creation failure due to incorrect control key flags.
  • KBA 3394874: Explains logic when using APIs to create components that default to "Never".
  • SAP Note 1980996 / 1523450: (Historical references) Often cited in SAP community discussions regarding intermittent resets of external processing indicators in ERP and S/4HANA environments.

entry.title: SAP Community Hobbies Series: Legos, Motorbikes and Vintage Cars
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

My name is Pierre, and I'm 62 yo.

I worked as a Senior Director, Product Communications at SAP, first for SAP Intelligent RPA as Head of Communications then for SAP Build as the oldest member, by far ðŸ˜‰, of the Product Communications and Enablement Team, with wonderful colleagues that I miss. ðŸ©µ

Since April 2025, I'm not actively working for SAP anymore, as I was lucky enough to be eligible for the Voluntary Early Retiring Plan launched by SAP in 2024. On one side I really miss the wonderful colleagues I was working with, but on the other side I'm very happy to have more time for my hobbies.

So Iâ€™d like to share a bit about my hobbies as a part of the  SAP Community Hobbies series.

 

First hobby: building Legos

I have always loved building things with Lego: my brother Jean-FranÃ§ois and I got our first Lego set when I was 5, and throughout our childhood we played Lego a lot, with our father guiding us. We built houses, castles, and also vehicles with the electric motor etc.

Then in 1978, at age 15, I discovered the first microcomputers, and I turned away a bit from Lego to code my first computer programs.
You will find more about my beginnings as a progammer in the blog post Blog it Forward â€“ Pierre Col I published exactly 6 years ago.

It's also because I love building from scratch that I was very happy to work for SAP Build: this low-code + pro-code solution allows business users and developers to very easily build applications, automated processes, and websites.

For Christmas 2024, my youngest daughter offered me the Lego Porsche 911 set: 1458 parts, to build either a Turbo or a Targa. I have completed the building in a few months:

I like this activity very much, because building Legos really helps me relaxing.
To be continued!

 

Second hobby: riding my vintage bikes

You will understand that I'm a petrolhead. ðŸ˜‰

First, I have always been into motorbikes, because my father was a biker.

From Norton...

In 1973, when I was 10 yo, he sold the Norton 88 I've ever seen in the garage to buy a magnificent  '1970 Norton Commando.

And every morning he was driving me to the high school, on the way to his work. You can easily imagine how proud I was...

My father always kept this bike in his garage, riding it until he was 75 yo. When I was visiting my parents, I regularly did some small tours on the Norton to keep it up and running.

When my father passed, almost 4 years ago, in accordance with my brother I inherited his bike. I did not ride it since then, and I will spend some time this Spring to restart it and ride it again in the countryside around Lyon...

You can hear the wonderful sound of the Norton Twin roaring here:

... to Honda...

In 1981, my first motorbike was a Honda 750 Four. With 67 hp for 220 kg, it was for me an incredibly powerful bike. In 1987 I bought a Honda CB 900 Bol d'Or which I still own:

I lent it in 1997 to an uncle living in Grenoble, he stills ride it but as he is 75yo now I imagine that he won't ride it for very long and I should get the 900 Bol d'Or back in my garage in a couple of years.

... and finally to Ducati

Since 1997, I ride Ducati motorbikes. It started with a 916, then I had a 350 Mark3 Desmo, a 900 Supersport, a 998 S, a Desmosedici RR and a Panigale 1299 R Final Edition. Yes, I really like fast red bike made in Bologna!

The Panigale Final Edition, with 209 hp for 168 kg, was the most powerful and amazing bike I'ev ever ridden. Indeed, even if it was a MotoGP replica with a V4 engine revving up to 14,200 rpm, the Desmosedici RR was not as efficient as the Panigale...

And I really enjoyed the very light and agile '1973 350 Mark3 Desmo I had during a few years, riding it on teh road as on tracks:

Unfortunately, fancy bikes attract thieves: bought in 1997, my 916 was stolen in 1999. My 998 S bought in 2002 and my rare Desmosedici RR #282 bought in 2007 were stolen in 2011. And my Panigale 1299 R Final Edition #322 bought in 2017 was stolen in 2023.

After some bastards stole my Panigale, I refurbished my good old '1994 900 Supersport which I bought in 2000, and lent to a friend from 2004 to 2019. I'm really enjoying riding this light (180 kg) and powerful enough (80 hp) bike on the curvy road in the hills, one hour northwest from Lyon:

 

Third hobby: driving my vintage 911 Porsche cabriolet

In 2011, right after insurance reimbursed my stolen Desmosedici RR, a good friend of mine decided to sell his 1990 Porsche 911 Carrera 2 cabriolet. It was the same car that hank Moody was driving in "Californication", but in better shape, with 135,000 km on the odometer. ðŸ˜‰

We quickly had a deal, and since more than 14 years I enjoy riding this vintage car, in any weather condition. I just passed 180,000 km and it works perfectly fine. According to my mechanic, my Porsche could reach 250,000 km without any trouble, and as I drive less than 5,000 km per year, for sure it will survive me:


As my wife will be very busy in May 2026, I decided that I will do a "5,000 km in 3-4 weeks" road trip across Central Europe in my Porsche 911: I will pay a visit to my former colleagues in Walldorf, Berlin and maybe a few other cities in Germany before heading to Poland, Hungary, Slovakia, Czech Republic, Austria, Switzerland...

 

Feel free to say hello if you would like me to pay you a visit, between May 1st and May 23: I will be more than happy to let you drive my Porsche in your neighborhood! ðŸ˜Š

entry.title: Re: Custom fields for enterprise search (SAP Cloud ERP)
entry.content:
Dear @Marlene10,

Question 1.

Enterprise Search in Public Cloud is not one single universal index over every object. Itâ€™s a set of search models that must be delivered and lifecycle-managed by SAP per object, including:

  • a CDS-based model and generated technical artifacts like ESH_* views
  • authorization handling
  • performance/index update considerations
  • and an explicit extension contract so key-user custom fields can be added

The Manage Search Models app is designed around that concept, it lets key users adjust SAP-delivered search models and create custom search models but only where the underlying model/view is available and supported for this

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/0f58c1ae4d804b6ea4e00649aa356438.html

Also SAP explicitly notes that HANA restrictions apply to search models and recommends limiting fields this is one of the reasons SAP enables/extensibility selectively it has to be safe at scale in a multi-tenant SaaS

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/2bf44249eb6c4210919e0b24e8739b91.html

Question 2.

No supported workaround in Public Cloud if SAP hasnâ€™t enabled extensibility for that delivered model.

Supported alternative CAN BE Create your own Custom Search Model this is the clean Public Cloud way to get searchable custom fields into Enterprise Search

What you get: Users can search those documents including your custom fields from the global Enterprise Search as a separate result type your custom model
What you donâ€™t get: You typically wonâ€™t inject fields into SAPâ€™s standard PO/Outbound Delivery result type if SAP hasnâ€™t opened it

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/0e602d466b99490187fcbb30d1dc897c/6d471dfc743048c3891601fa8ab0dc1e.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/7c05c3429f0f438a922d3caa302cef3f.html

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/7793ac82d8f441debff749523b829490.html

If youâ€™re in a 3-system landscape, SAP also supports transporting search model changes so you can move the custom model across systems properly

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/a630d57fc5004c6383e7a81efee7a8bb/d6863cf1b25a439881a4447cc892d61d.html

Question 3.

From publicly available information I canâ€™t CONFIRM/FIND a specific roadmap item that explicitly says extend Enterprise Search custom fields for Purchase Orders / Outbound Deliveries

What is supported and effective in Public Cloud is to push this via SAP Customer Influence, SAP even has note explaining how to submit feature requests

SAP Note below:

https://me.sap.com/notes/0002963059

Summary:

What youâ€™re seeing is unfortunately expected in Public Cloud because Enterprise Search extensibility is only available for business objects where SAP has delivered a CDS-based search model and explicitly opened it for key-user extension

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Why are self-joins designed for tables in SAP Universe
entry.content: Why are self-joins designed for tables in SAP Universe, and what are the benefits of this design? and are both aliases for , but when querying and , they originate from different alias tables. SELECT FACT_SHIPMENT.STT_NB, FACT_SHIPMENT_METRICS.GROSS_WEIGHT FROM AOR.AORFCT_SHIPMENT_UNION_V FACT_SHIPMENT_METRICS INNER JOIN AOR.AORFCT_SHIPMENT_UNION_V FACT_SHIPMENT ON (FACT_SHIPMENT_METRICS.SHIPMENT_KEY=FACT_SHIPMENT.SHIPMENT_KEY) WHERE FACT_SHIPMENT.STT_NB IN ('xxxxxxxx' )

entry.title: Re: What is the difference between Count([City]) and Coun...
entry.content: By default, COUNT() will count DISTINCT values only. Using the eFashion universe, a DISTINCT count of [State] is 8.   A count of ALL [State] is 11.  =Count([State];All)

entry.title: Re: Price in Work Order
entry.content:
How SAP determines component price in Work Orders is based on the following:

Valuation Area = Plant
In SAP, material valuation is at plant level (or company code if valuation is at company code level). Each plant can have different valuation classes, moving average prices, or standard prices for the same material.

Work Order Operation Plant
When you create a work order, the operation plant defines the valuation area for costing. The system assumes that the material will be issued from that plantâ€™s inventory to the order.

Component Tab Pricing
When you assign a component, SAP looks up the material master price (standard price or moving average) in the plant of the operation. That is why the price is not just based on the material, but on the material + plant combination.

Consistency with Costing & Settlement
This ensures that the order cost reflects the actual valuation of the material in the plant where the operation is executed. If you change the operation plant, the component valuation will change accordingly.

For example, material RM01 has:

  • Price in Plant 1000 = â‚¹50
  • Price in Plant 2000 = â‚¹60

Work Order created in Plant 1000 â†’ Component RM01 shows â‚¹50.

Work Order created in Plant 2000 â†’ Component RM01 shows â‚¹60.

The difference is because SAP always reads the valuation data of the plant in the operation.

entry.title: Re: Price in Work Order
entry.content: To ensure that the costing reflects the actual conditions and agreements relevant to the specific plant where the work order is being executed, but what is your requirement ?

entry.title: Re: SAP BTP - IS - How to become a SAP Integration Suite Consultant beyond SAP CPI - SAP APIM Part I
entry.content:
@rhviana Great showcase of APIM use cases.
I would add one more superb material - conversation from LinkedIn which @vinaymittal initiated (if anyone missed it few months ago -> must read)
https://www.linkedin.com/posts/vinay-mittal_i-often-get-asked-if-we-should-put-sap-api-activity-7401965389984768000-rKr6/ 

Conclusion: Deploy API Management only when you have specific requirements for API proxy capabilities that Cloud Integration cannot natively support. CI is already designed for secure external access and includes robust security measures. Adding an additional proxy layer through APIM introduces unnecessary complexity without meaningful benefit unless those specialized proxy features are genuinely needed

br

Mateusz

entry.title: How to group requirements across several WBS using valuated project stock?
entry.content:
We are in the steel structure industry; our finished goods are pieces of steel that are cut, bent, drilled and marked with finished good number.

We are using Project System for costing and SD for logistics processes. Our requirement is to work with valuated project stock as the finished goods often sit in inventory more than 1 month. This is also to align with the contractual billing agreement and COGS recognition.

We want to analyze our costs per WBS element which for us are sections of the steel tower.  (The entire tower is a Project). 

We are using the Mill Products solution which means we use Combined Orders so that many pieces of steel are cut at the same time under a single Header Order/operation but then after that operation is confirmed each finished good continues to be made under a separate Child Order within this Combined Order.  We cannot combine any secondary operations such as bending, drilling, etc. because each piece of steel that was cut under the Header order follows a different routing with different secondary operations.

We need to create a single Combined Order across several WBS elements so that production quantities are large enough. To do â€œrequirements groupingâ€ across several WBS elements SAP offers these 2 solutions.  We are using S/4HANA version 2021.

  1. PMMO â€“ not acceptable because it works with only non-valuated stock; we need to use valuated stock
  2. GPD â€“ GPD is deprecated but it does work with both valuated stock and non-valuated stock BUT it doesnâ€™t do FI postings, it does only CO postings and moreover within a CO version that is not 0; this does not work for us reporting wise both in S/4 and in our reporting tool.

Any suggestions as to how to structure such a model to optimize the production and at the same time obtain the detailed financial recordings as stated above?

Thank you very much!

entry.title: Graph on Integration Suite: Simplifying Multi-API Data Retrieval with Unified Business Data Graph
entry.content:
Graph is a new and innovative feature of API Management, part of the SAP Integration Suite. Expanding on traditional API Management, Graph allows you to present all your business data as a semantically connected data graph, accessible through a single, unified, and powerful API.

Graph in SAP Integration Suite is now available for a limited time as a closed beta program and includes the following new features:

  • A configuration UI for creating business data graphs â€“ an extension of the new Integration Suite configuration UI.
  • The ability to extend the built-in Graph data model.
  • Graph Navigator (Enterprise Edition) â€“ a tool for exploring and testing queries on your configured business data graphs.
  • GraphQL support (in addition to OData v4).

Graph Capability in Integration Suite:

Graph can be used in any SAP Integration Suite plan where API Management is available (including SAP BTP trial accounts), but not necessarily in every region where API Management is available. For more details about the regional availability of Graph, be sure to check out SAP Note 3338820.

Enabling Graph on your Integration Suite

Ensuring the Required Roles and Enabling Graph

  1. Make sure you have the Integration Suite Provisioner role.
  2. Navigate to "Manage Capabilities" â†’ "Add Capabilities" in your Integration Suite home.
  3. Enable API Management (if not already enabled) through the "Manage APIs" section.
  4. Enable API Business Hub Enterprise and Graph (API Business Hub Enterprise is mandatory for Graph).
  5. If Graph is not visible, refer to SAP Note 3338820, as it may not be supported in your region.
  6. Select "Enable API Business Hub Enterprise" and "Graph" to complete the setup.

Note: Graph requires SAP API Management to be activated.

Assigning Roles for Graph

Once Graph is enabled, you will see two additional Role Collections in the SAP BTP Cockpit:

  • Graph.KeyUser â€“ A role for Graph Developers to define Business Data Graphs (BDGs).
  • GraphNavigator.Viewer â€“ A role for viewing graphs in Graph Navigator.

To proceed, go to your SAP BTP Cockpit and assign these Role Collections to your user.

Note the term: Business Data Graphs. SAP refers to Graphs as BDGs or Business Data Graphs in their documentation.

That's it, you are all set for Configuring BDGs or Business Data Graphs! Logout and Log back on Integration Suite and you will now see Graphs Enabled in Integration Suite under Design Tab.

 

Enable SAP Graph Entitlement on BTP Subaccount

In below screenshot Graph entitlement is enabled

To enable SAP Graph (Business Data Graphs - BDGs) in your BTP Subaccount, follow these steps:

  1. Navigate to your BTP Subaccount.
  2. Go to Entitlements â†’ Configure Entitlements.
  3. Click "Add Service Plans".
  4. Select SAP Graph and choose the api service plan.
  5. Save your changes to apply the entitlement.

Creating a Service Instance for SAP Graph

  1. Go to your BTP Subaccount.
  2. Navigate to Services â†’ Instances and Subscriptions.
  3. Click "Create" and select SAP Graph as the service.
  4. Choose the api plan.
  5. Provide a name for your service instance.
  6. Click "Create" to finalize the setup.

Creating a Service Key for SAP Graph

  1. Go to your BTP Subaccount.
  2. Navigate to Services â†’ Instances and Subscriptions.
  3. Find the SAP Graph service instance you created in the previous step.
  4. Click on the instance and select "Create Service Key".
  5. Provide a name for the service key and click "Create".
  6. Once generated, copy and save the Service Key, as it will be required for exploring Business Data Graphs (BDGs) using Postman.

The Graph instance is created and Binded with its Service Key:

Once your Service Key is created, make sure to note the following details:

  •  clientid â€“ Required for authentication.
  •  clientsecret â€“ Used for authentication along with the client ID.
  •  url â€“ This is the Token URL used to obtain authentication tokens.
  • uri â€“ Contains the hostname, which includes the GraphQL Endpoint hostname for accessing Business Data Graphs (BDGs).

You'll need these details when exploring BDGs using Postman or any API client.

 Graph Creation

Fetch Sales Order Details with Customer Details

Imagine a S/4Hana System, where you have a BusinessPartner API and SalesOrder API exposed. This could be a S/4Hana On-Premises System or a S/4Hana Public Cloud Edition System. These are classic ODATA APIs from SAP â€“ Business Partner ODATA API and Sales Order ODATA API.

Note: In my case Iâ€™m using SAP Business Accelerator Hub â€“ API HUB

Querying Sales Orders and Customer Details with SAP Graph

In a typical integration scenario, querying Sales Orders from SAP S/4HANA and fetching Customer Details (SoldToParty) involves:

  1. Making an OData GET request to the Sales Order API to retrieve Sales Order details.
  2. Making another OData GET request to the Business Partner API to fetch the corresponding SoldToParty details.
  3. Enriching the data using SAP Cloud Integration to combine the two datasets.

Since SAP provides this information through two separate APIs, this approach traditionally requires two API calls and additional processing to merge the data. However, with SAP Graph (BDGs - Business Data Graphs), you can simplify this by using a single GraphQL query to fetch Sales Orders and their associated Customer details in one call.

Simplifying Data Retrieval with SAP Graph

Traditionally, in SAP Cloud Integration, fetching Sales Order details along with SoldToParty (Customer Details) from S/4HANA Cloud requires:

  • Multiple OData API calls (one for Sales Orders, one for Business Partners).
  • Content Enrichers to merge and process the data.
  • Lookups to fetch related information across different API endpoints.

This is a common challenge when integrating SAP and non-SAP SaaS applications.

The Power of SAP Graph (BDGs - Business Data Graphs)

With SAP Graph on Integration Suite, you can retrieve all this data in one API callâ€”with no custom development!

SAP Graph introduces the concept of Mirrored Entities, which allows you to:

  • Access data from multiple APIs as a single, unified data model.
  • Query related entities (e.g., Sales Orders and SoldToParty) in a single request.
  • Reduce integration complexity and eliminate the need for multiple lookups/enrichers.

Whatâ€™s Next?

Weâ€™ll explore Mirrored Entities in SAP Graph and see how they can simplify fetching Sales Order details along with Customer details from an Business Accelerator Hubâ€”all in one call.

Creating Destinations on SAP BTP

To integrate SAP Graph with your S/4HANA Cloud or On-Premise system, you need to create destinations on your BTP Subaccount.

Prerequisites

  • You have your OData API endpoint for Sales Orders and Business Partners.
  • A Technical Communication User is set up with the required roles and permissions to access these APIs.

Steps to Create Destinations in BTP

  1. Navigate to BTP Cockpit
    • Go to your BTP Subaccount where Integration Suite / Graph is running.
    • Open the Destinations section.
  2. Create a Destination for Sales Orders API

  1. Create a Destination for Business Partner API

Setting Up a Business Data Graph in Integration Suite

Next, weâ€™ll create a Business Data Graph (BDG) in SAP Integration Suite. To get started, go to Integration Suite â†’ Design â†’ Graph.

Once destination as source are added, click next, review the configurations, below screen will appear in a while after processing

Click on Activate.

Test Your Graph on Graph Navigator

 

 

Validating Graph OData API

As discussed earlier, all Business Data Graphs (BDGs) created in SAP Integration Suite are accessible via OData V4 APIs, as documented in SAP's official guides.

Now, weâ€™ll use the Service Key generated in the previous step to obtain an OAuth token and authenticate our request to test the Graph OData API.

Note the URI in your Service Key has the format

https://<subdomain>.a.integration.cloud.sap/graph/api

List all BDGs

 List all Services of a BDG (namespace)

List all namespaces of a Specific BDG. Namespaces can be sap.s4, sap.graph, sap.hcm and so on.

List all Entities in a namespace in a BDG

Entities of a Graph can be displayed using below

Get Metadata of a Service (Namespace)

Test our Service to get Sales Order Details with SoldToParty

In our example this will be in below format

  • Use _SoldToParty for expanding SoldToParty ( note the â€œunderscoreâ€). Thats the standard Graph Notation when you have automatic associations built ( from Sales Order to Business Partner API in our case )

That's it! We have successfully invoked your Graph OData V4 API and retrieved Sales Order data enriched with Business Partner details.

What would typically require a two-step process using a Content Enricher in Cloud Integration is now streamlined into a single API callâ€”thanks to Graph on Integration Suite.

 SAP Graph has the below GraphQL endpoint :

https://<subdomain>.a.integration.cloud.sap/graph/api/<bdg>/graphql

entry.title: Regarding User Licence..
entry.content:
Hi There,

I want to know if need any SAP crystal licence in my case.

We use â€œSAP Crystal Report 2020 Support Pack 4 Patch 12 (CR Developer)â€ licenced version to design RPT files and formulate them to to generate/save reports in TXT file.

A C# desktop application use â€œSAP Crystal Report Runtime Engine For .NET Framework (32 bit)â€, installed on same machine where C# application running, to load Crystal Reference Libraries at runtime to load RPT files and save report locally in TXT format. This C# application perform all database related stuff to fetch data to feed RPT files and save report in TXT file. All database related stuff is done in this C# application only.

Now three following things needs to be delivered to customer to generate report:

  • RPT files designed with licensed Crystal2020
  • C# application which loads RPT at runtime and feed data.
  • SAP Crystal Report Runtime Engine For .NET Framework (32 bit)

 

Customer want to use VDI (mstsc) to install all above three locally in virtual machine and generate/save report locally in virtual machine.

Now I want to know if we need â€œSAP Crystal Report Runtime Engine For .NET Framework (32 bit)â€ licence or any other SAP licence for this case?

Please help me out.

Thanks

entry.title: Comparison of Rate Routing and Routing in SAP
entry.content:
Overview

In SAP Production Planning (PP), Routing and Rate Routing are both task lists that define manufacturing operations. While they share similarities, they cater to different manufacturing scenarios and differ in time calculation, setup requirements, and application contexts.

Comparison Table


 
 
Parameter
Rate RoutingRouting
Definition
Defines production quantity and fixed duration to establish production rates.Defines a sequence of operations with detailed times for each step.
Primary Use Case
Repetitive manufacturing and flow production.Discrete manufacturing and production orders.
Time Definition
Based on production rate (quantity per time period).Based on setup, processing, and teardown times per operation.
Setup Time
Typically not defined.Defined for each operation.
Manufacturing Type
Repetitive/Flow manufacturing.Discrete manufacturing.
Sequence Types
Standard and parallel sequences only.Standard, parallel, and alternative sequences.
Transaction Codes
CA21 (Create), CA22 (Change), CA23 (Display).CA01 (Create), CA02 (Change), CA03 (Display).
Costing Approach
Period-based costing.Order-based costing.

Key Differences

  • Time Calculation:
    • Rate Routing â†’ Defines production rates (quantity per time).
    • Routing â†’ Defines operation times (time per quantity).
  • Sequence Flexibility:
    • Rate Routing â†’ No alternative sequences (only standard and parallel).
    • Routing â†’ Supports alternative sequences.
  • Manufacturing Philosophy:
    • Rate Routing â†’ Designed for lean, continuous production.
    • Routing â†’ Suited for varied discrete manufacturing scenarios.

When to Use Each

Rate Routing

  • For repetitive manufacturing with continuous production flows.
  • When products are made in large volumes with consistent rates.
  • In flow manufacturing environments with minimal setup changes.
  • When using Product Cost Collectors (PCC) for period-based costing.
  • For assembly backflush scenarios (e.g., transaction MFBF).

Routing

  • For discrete manufacturing with varied lot sizes.
  • When alternative sequences or flexible operations are required.
  • When detailed setup, processing, and teardown times are needed.
  • For order-based production with specific requirements.

Common Misconceptions

  • Interchangeability: While both can be used in repetitive manufacturing, Rate Routing is recommended for REM due to its design for continuous production and backflushing compatibility.
  • Functionality: Rate Routing offers similar functions as Routing but is optimized for rate-based production.
  • Alternative Sequences: The absence of alternative sequences in Rate Routing is intentional, aligning with standardized repetitive processes.

Recommendation

  • Choose Rate Routing for repetitive manufacturing with standardized processes, continuous flows, and period-based costing.
  • Choose Routing for discrete manufacturing requiring operational flexibility, alternative sequences, and detailed time definitions.

Your choice should align with your manufacturing strategy and costing approach.

Additional Reference

Rate Routing 

Maintaining Routings and Rate Routings

entry.title: Re: A Handy Custom Report to Scan SAP CDS Views for Usage of Search Strings
entry.content:
Awesome contribution to the community.  Very useful.  

Adding a few of my own quick hits for similar searches:
Most useful to me so far: 

HANA SQL
SELECT DDLNAME FROM "SAPHANADB"."DDDDLSRC" where ddlname like 'I_%' and source like '%group by%' limit 20

ABAP SQL 

LIST CDS VIEWS HAVING A SPECIFIC HEADER LEVEL ANNOTATION (Update WHERE Clause)
    SELECT 
        HEAD1~STRUCOBJN AS ViewName,
        HEAD1~NAME         AS Annotation,     
        HEAD1~VALUE        AS Value,
        HEAD2~NAME         AS VDMType,
        HEAD2~VALUE        AS VDMTypeValue
    FROM DDHEADANNO AS HEAD1
    LEFT JOIN DDHEADANNO AS HEAD2
        ON  HEAD1~STRUCOBJN = HEAD2~STRUCOBJN AND HEAD2~NAME = 'VDM.VIEWTYPE'
    WHERE ( HEAD1~strucobjn like 'Z%' and HEAD1~NAME = 'ANALYTICS.QUERY' )
    ORDER BY ViewName
LIST CDS VIEWS HAVING A SPECIFIC HEADER LEVEL ANNOTATION (Update WHERE Clause)

       SELECT HEAD1~STRUCOBJN    AS ViewName, 
              HEAD1~NAME         AS Annotation,   
              HEAD1~VALUE        AS Value,
              HEAD2~NAME         AS VDMType,
              HEAD2~VALUE        AS VDMTypeValue
        FROM DDHEADANNO AS HEAD1 
            LEFT JOIN DDHEADANNO AS HEAD2
                ON  HEAD1~STRUCOBJN = HEAD2~STRUCOBJN AND HEAD2~NAME = 'VDM.VIEWTYPE' 
       WHERE ( HEAD1~NAME = 'ANALYTICS.DATACATEGORY' and HEAD1~VALUE = '#CUBE' )
*       WHERE ( HEAD1~NAME = 'ANALYTICS.DATACATEGORY' and HEAD1~VALUE = '#DIMENSION' )
*       WHERE ( HEAD1~NAME = 'ANALYTICS.DATACATEGORY' and HEAD1~VALUE = '#FACT' )
*       WHERE ( HEAD1~NAME = 'ANALYTICS.DATACATEGORY' and HEAD1~VALUE = '#TEXT' ) 
*       WHERE ( HEAD1~NAME = 'ANALYTICS.DATACATEGORY' and HEAD1~VALUE = '#HIERARCHY' )                                  
       ORDER BY ViewName
* FIND CDS VIEWS NOT HAVING A SPECIFIC ANNOTATION ASSIGNMENT
SELECT DDHEADANNO~STRUCOBJN, 
       DDHEADANNO~NAME, 
       DDHEADANNO~VALUE
    FROM DDHEADANNO 
    WHERE NAME = 'VDM.VIEWTYPE' 
      AND STRUCOBJN NOT IN ( SELECT STRUCOBJN FROM DDHEADANNO WHERE NAME = 'ANALYTICS.DATACATEGORY' )
   ORDER BY STRUCOBJN

entry.title: Re: What is the difference between Count([City]) and Coun...
entry.content:
The COUNT function is generally a measure that aggregates based on the dimensions.  The default COUNT only counts unique values of the object whereas the COUNT ALL will count all occurrences including duplicates.

For instance, with the 5 sample rows below, if you put COUNT([CITY]) in a subtotal, it is 3 but a COUNT([CITY];All) returns 5.  If you replace the CITY column object with a COUNT, the data aggregates to 3 rows with JOHN having a value of 2 and JANE just 1.  Whereas a COUNT ALL would return 2 for both JOHN and JANE.

JOHNCHICAGO
JOHNAUSTIN
JANECHICAGO
JANETRENO
JANECHICAGO

entry.title: Release highlights of Signavio Process Insights 2512 with process variant analysis
entry.content:
SAP  Signavio  Process  Analysis  and Mining  has released the December release (2512) of Signavio Process Insights. As announced earlier by Silvio Arcangeli we made a bold step in unifying Process Insights and Process Intelligence by adding the process variant analysis for selected process flows. Furthermore we have a Beta version the "business process map" capability which allows signed Beta customer a glimpse into the business object mining capabilities. Here is a quick demo of the general available capabilities (incl. process variant analysis) of 2512:

Here you find the Beta version which will only be available to signed Beta customers:

 

Here you can learn more about Process Analysis and Mining:

  1. See SAP Signavio Process Insights, Process Intelligence and Plug & Gain in action
  2. Your first steps to get started with SAP Signavio Process Insights
  3. Who do I need to involve and which challenges do I want to solve?
  4. How to start your analysis?
  5. â€œCash is Kingâ€ - but how to become royal? - SAP Community
  6. Why are there two business process analysis soluti... - SAP Community
  7. Plug & Gain:
    • Plug & Gain Video Series and Plug & Gain OpenSAP
    • How to use the Plug & Gain Connector
    • Optimize financial closing process with Plug & Gain
  1. SAP Analytics Cloud Content for Process Insights
  2. SAP Learning:
    SAP Signavio Process Analysis
    SAP Signavio Process Management & Design
    SAP Signavio Solution Configuration
  3. Partner Edge (Login required): Webinar Series for Process Insights
  4. SAP Signavio Process Insights "Whats New?"
  5. SAP Signavio Process Insights Help

entry.title: Analysis for Office insert Datasource dialog only shows queries. InfoProviders not showing.
entry.content:
In my Quality System I am getting an AO Report Error that the DataSource is not found.

I create an AO Report in DEV over a CDS View Transient Provider of type DIMENSION. 
This is done by opening up a blank workbook and doing a search and insert for the DIMENSION Provider.  This works great.

In my Dev System:
Creating a new AO Report by searching and inserting a DataSource shows both Queries and Providers available for selection.

In my Quality and Production System:
Creating a new AO Report by searching and inserting a DataSource shows only Queries available for selection. 
No providers are showing up at all for selection as I do in my Dev system.  
I verified that the Transient Provider is available in Quality system using transaction RSRTS_ODP_DIS. 

Would anyone know what or where I should spend my time figuring out why I only see Queries and not Providers in Quality?  

Thanks for any input on this issue.
